results.title: The Crying Game
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and John Wood
results.brief_description:
A personal account created by a participant in the ACMI Digital Storytelling Workshop Telling Tales. Produced in partnership with Arts Access and supported by the Department of Human Services and the Deafness Foundation for Telling Tales.
This story made by John Wood talks about his uncontrallable bouts of crying. This is sometimes brought about by depression or anxiety. He has learned that the expression of emotion is very healthy.

results.title: Why?
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Tehree Gordon
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Tehree says she is an ordinary Australian, though she was a recipient of the Senior Australian of the Year Award in 2004. In this story, Tehree talks about her passion for wildlife from an early age leading to her founding Jirrahlinga Koala and Wildlife Sanctuary with her partner Hamish. The sanctuary has provided work opportunities and enrichment to people living with disabilities and the elderly.

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 - Red
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 Red was broadcast as the first of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Space Between the Gaps (Paul Gafney), abcTVxyz (Dale Nason), The Visitor (Andrew Till) and Third Eye (Ollie Olsen).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 1 Red is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection [event version]
results.brief_description:
‘Cyberthon III: The Underground Connection’ was the third broadcast event in the Cyberthon series, held at TVU’s (Television Unlimited) warehouse and studio in Footscray Victoria. Increasing again in scope and complexity from Cyberthon II, Cyberthon III collaborators invited ten local bands, ten local DJ’s and 3RRR radio hosts Kate Bathgate and Liz Miller to interview artists and participants live at the event. This was in addition to the extensive DV and VJ sets, live artist performances, electronic art and installations on displays. Viewers were also encouraged to interact with participating artists via a bulletin board system (BBS) or fax in a Cyberthon event first.

This is the event version of ‘Cyberthon-III: the underground connection’ to see the [1 hour compilation] see title B2004315

Visual Artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Cyber Dada (Dale Nason and Troy Innocent), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton and Attillio Gangemi), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson)

Audio Artists: Darren Jackson (Geeza), Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume (1x4x9), Soulscraper (Chris Dubrow, Sarah Lord, James Lynch, Elanor Rayner & Jim Shnookal), H2o (Terence Ho ), Vertigo Hypo (Bryan St James & Narelle Wellington), 2120 (Claude Young Jr), Hardware (Richie ‘Rich’ McNeil), Poets of the Machine (Coral and Stripe), The Visitor (Andrew Till), Liz Millar, This Digital Ocean (Liz Millar, Ross Healy & Simon Bowley), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Blast Off Sound System (Jason ‘Rudeboy’ Mac), Miss Baby Lemonade Lemarr (Andrea), Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Whip (Kent Morris, Michelle, Mirella, Simon), Geeza (Darren Jackson), Wesley McDonald

Performers: Tranzmission (Kate Bathgate), Liz Millar, Every Picture Tells a Story (Hydi John), Central Station (Joe Polumbo), Yoga (Mary Galick, Eugene-NRG (Paul Gafney) & Bronwyn Richie), Mad Club (Bernie Grogan, Danny Slim, Susan Clinch & Matt the Tree), Taz (Tasilim Emiabata), Star (Raquel Webb), Lizette Broulathaki and Jynell Dolan.

Cyberthon II: The Virtual Transmission is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Cyberthon VI: VAT
results.brief_description:
After the success of Spectrum, the Cyberthon artists were invited by Telstra to create a submission for an exhibition called The Edge, to be displayed at the Telstra Corporate Center on Exhibition Street. This demo was presented to Telstra at an annual meeting held at Dallas Brooks Hall.

The demo shows a CGI artists impression of the proposed ‘The Edge exhibition’ space as well as a simulation of the media submission process via the interactive Cyberthon VAT (V=Video, A=Audio, T=Text) porthole created using Deluxe Paint, with presentation edited in Scala on an Amiga 2000.

Animation loops that appear in simulated submission section were created by Ian Haig, Cyber Dada (Troy Innocent and Dale Nason), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton & Attillio Gangemi), Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Julian Wong, Mish Fingers (Misha Hollenbach), Derek Shiel, Martine Corompt, and Force Fed (Stuart McCormick). Video camera footage was shot by Dale Nason from the back of a Chris Wrights moving van. 35mm still photographs were taken by Tao Wiess. Audio track was mixed by DJ Visitor (Andrew Till).

This work is part of the Cyberthon Archive, generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: [Stelarc: Event for Modified Man 1976]
results.brief_description:
This video is documentation of a performance entitled “Modulate / Meditate: Event for Modified Man” held at Tamura Gallery in Tokyo, Japan, from 26 January to 1 February 1976.

In this durational performance, Stelarc has hooks inserted into his back and sews first his lips and then his eyelids closed with a needle and thread. In the gallery are TV monitors including one showing an X-ray of his own body. Standing in the centre of the gallery with the hooks attached to the wall behind him, the artist captures the sounds of his own body – heartbeat, breath and blood rushing – which are then amplified throughout the space. In the latter part of the video, the participation of the body comes to an end: the artist removes the stitches from his eyelids and mouth and the hooks are removed.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.

results.title: Time changes
results.brief_description: “Time changes” is an experimental, self-reflexive film, comprised of footage filmed over four years by Sue Ford and her friends. Described by the artist as being “a documentary about time and change, focusing on four men who were filmmakers and close friends”, the film features friends Stuart Green, Chris Maudson, John Phillips and Paul Reed, as well as Ford, her children Emma and Ben, and artists Richard Brennan, Bonita Ely, Margo Nash and Ashe Venn. Through unscripted dialogue, the friends’ conversations range across topics such as the integrity of filmmaking and creative practice to ways of living and relationships.

group_siblings.title: Egami

production_dates.notes: Previously catalogued as 1977, updated to 1978 following research by Julia Murphy 6 Apr 2022

results.title: Egami
results.creator_credit: Victorian Women's Film Unit and Sue Ford
results.brief_description: In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Melbourne landmarks are totalitarian monuments, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

constellations_primary.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_primary.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian Women’s Film Unit and Sue Ford
results.description: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.
description_for_label: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

results.title: Pifuskin
results.brief_description: Sometimes a man just has to scratch. This short animation explores notions of iritation of skin, of perception of self, of blood and bodily function.

results.title: Cyborg Chicken
results.brief_description:
In the hen-house, the story of the brave ‘Cyborg Chicken’ is passed down from the Old Master Rooster to the next generation. A story about difference, courage and saving the future, ending with a call to “STOP Global Warming!”.
Voice acting: Anthony Baptiste, Marcus Marshall, Kelsey Noel.
Production design: Kelsey Noel.
Character design: Dominic Ross
